Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the promise I’d made to my son echoing in my mind. He’d been saving up, counting the days until I could buy him that Nintendo. As a parent, I wanted to keep my word, to see his face light up with joy. But the bills on the counter reminded me of my other responsibility—ensuring we stayed afloat. Just then, my phone buzzed. A homeowner’s voice crackled through, urgent about a damaged deck that needed immediate repair. As a carpenter, I knew the job couldn’t wait; the deck was unsafe, and my reputation depended on quick, quality work. The job would take hours, maybe days, and I’d have to buy materials upfront. My mind raced, torn between the promise to my child and the duty to my craft. If I took the job, I might have to delay the Nintendo. If I didn’t, I risked losing a client and much-needed income. My heart ached, caught between the expectations of being a good parent and a reliable carpenter, unsure which role to answer first.
